intro: Overview: When your drinking a coors light it is easy to tell whether it’s the right temperature (see link https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cv2a-Yzzr_o&list=WL&index=2 ), but if your drinking literally anything else there is no way to tell. That is why I set out to find a cheap and easy way to tell the temperature of your drink without playing russian roulette with your tongue. My device makes it as simple as possible, you just put your drink in the holder, press a button and like magic the temperature sensor will take reading and the servo will rotate revealing a red light for cold enough and a green for too hot.

1. Step 1: Base

Étapes :

  1. Cut a 18 in x 24in piece of cardboard

2. Step 2: Drink Holder

Étapes :

  1. Cut four 2.5 in x 2 in pieces of cardboard
  2. In the middle of one piece cut an opening for your temperature sensor
  3. Glue the four pieces of cardboard to the base (on the corner about half a cm in) longside down to form a square holder

3. Step 3: Mountain/Cover

Étapes :

  1. Make a triangle that is 16 in (length) x 6 in (height)
  2. 3 in in cut out another triangle in the shaping it like 2 mountains similar to the coors light can
  3. Cut 4 small triangles .5 in x .5 in to use as supports
  4. Cut on .5 in x 1 in square
  5. Glut to the base half an in behind the holder so .5 in are covered on one side
  6. Glue the four triangles to the cover on the back side to form supports, then glue the square to the rectangle and case from the otherside as a support
  7. Cut another rectangle and glue it at the taller peak to use as a light holder
  8. Cut two circles out 5 in up and in the middle of the taller peak

4. Step 4: Covering Case

Étapes :

  1. Cut a 3 in diameter circle out of cardboard and trim the sides so it can rotate on the face of the backside of the cover in between the lights and holes.

5. Step 5: Stand/ Servo

Étapes :

  1. Glue cardboard squares together 3 in high and glue the servo to the top.

6. Step 6: Final Assembly

Étapes :

  1. Glue the covering case to the servo arm and attach it to the servo.
  2. Glue the servo to the board so the middle of the cover case is skimming the back of the mountain and it is covering both of the holes.
  3. Put the lights in the back holder so they are lined with the holes.
  4. Place Arduino, the breadboard, and battery behind the holding case
